physDesc.p: This letter is 6 pages long (seq. 69-74). It is typed on good quality typing paper (neither notebook paper nor Lowell’s nice cardstock, but somewhere in between). The words “John Gould Fletcher” are written in pencil across the top of the first page.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your letter of September 25th has this minute come, and I was awfully interested to see what you said about the state of mind of our little group. My feeling is exactly yours. The “Anthology” has done exactly what I hoped it would do – in fact, it has done more than in my wildest dreams/ever dared to hope. But I think the moment for its usefulness has gone by. I don’t believe there is much point in having another. I think that another would sell about as well as this one has, which, I imagine, is not bad, that is, judging from their statement on the first of August. Since getting your letter I telephoned in to Ferris Greenslet, and he is to tell me the exact sale on Friday (to-morrow being a holiday) and I will add it as a postscript to this letter before sending it off.

I don’t, personally, think there is any real getting together between you and me and the other members of the group. I don’t count Lawrence, because he never was an Imagist and never cared a snap about the tenets. H.D. is, as you say, excessively narrow. I was awfully annoyed with her articles on Mary Anne Moore and a woman named Mew, in the August and September “Egoist”;they are so jejune and so over-praised. In fact, I have written her a letter objecting to that form of criticism coming from any one of our group, but I don't think I shall send the letter – at least, not in its present form, for I think that Hilda is pretty well overwrought. She is trying to do a job on that paper for which she is by no means fitted, and they have not seen me for so many years that I don’t believe they are very inclined to take my criticism on anything.

Personally, I should much rather not have any “Anthology” this year. I think the anthology business is run into the ground anyhow, with Braithwaite’s, and Harriet’s, and all the others, and I think the time has come when we have got to go it on our own. If we ever develop individually; it is quite plain that we cannot hold to the narrow tenets that please Hilda. But still, you know my sense of honour, and I said I would do it for three years, and I will.

Greenslet says that they are still going to print the “New Poetry Series,” but maybe they won’t call it that, and they are going to vary the covers of the individual volumes, which I think is a good idea. Our contract said nothing about the series anyway, and he is quite willing to carry it (the Anthology) on again this year; although he agrees with me that it has done its job.

Now from the letters that I have had from Richard and Hilda, I feel quite sure that they will both feel it a good deal if we abandon this year’s “Anthology”. I am afraid Hilda’s book is not going to sell at all over here, I don't know how it has done in England – do you? Maybe we are quits, because my books do not sell in England.

I had already made up my mind to send “Lacquer Prints” as my contribution. Whether they will make a full contribution or not I don’t know. I have not counted yet. If they do not, I will add something to them.

Your “Lincoln” is a superb poem. I was reading it again only yesterday, and I think you certainly must have it for one of your three. I see from Brown’s list that he is publishing your “Japanese Prints” as one of his little booklets. Evidently you have not instructed him to send me a copy, so I shall just go and get one.
My book is not out yet. I shall certainly send it to you as soon as it is. They hope to publish it a week from to-day, but I do not think they will get it out until the week after that.

I told Hilda to have the contributions here to me by the first of December, and that I would have mine over there by that date. I don’t know how to sound Richard and Hilda about this year’s “Anthology”, and as I am quite convinced from their letters that they want it, I guess we had better go ahead and round the thing up squarely.
Mr. Marsh tells me that the advance sale on "Men, Women, and Ghosts” is the best I have had for any book so far, even “Six French Poets,” which is hopeful.

I am fearfully tired, for I have just finished a long poem on Lord Nelson and Lady Hamilton, in polyphonic, a sort of companion piece to "Malmaison". Mrs. Russell thinks it is the strongest thing I have done, but she is the only person who has seen it so far – she and my secretary, and I guess they are both prejudiced. Anyhow, I am not going to do any more until I come back from Chicago and St. Louis, whither I am going in about ten days.

There is, to my mind, a chance that Richard may grow. You say he is already altered. But I don’t believe there is any hope of H.D.’s changing materially in any way, and I am quite sure that Flint is absolutely done. I am just as sick of being bound up in a group as you are. I still think that Imagism, as you and I interpret it, is a splendid movement, but narrowed, as H.D. would have us narrow it, I think means death. It does to me, anyhow. We should go ahead with this “Anthology’, however, as if it were all right, because I have already hinted to Richard and Hilda that I thought its usefulness was over, and as they have not taken the hint, I feel we had better finish up brown. Of course there is no question of there ever being another after this.

I still hope that you will change your mind about staying over there too long, because I believe distinctly that your future is here, although, of course, you must do as you think best. But from everything I hear about England, it is all war over there now.

People are pretty well wrought up here, with the German submarine exploits off Nantucket. I hope it will have a good effect at the election and bring Hughes in triumphantly. Wilson’s policy has been a disgrace to the country.
I wish I had been with you all at your meeting the other day. It is jolly homesick here without anybody. However, some day the war will end, and if you don’t come home, I can go over there.
body.postscript:
P.S.
Ferris Greenslet has just telephoned that we have sold 700 copies up to date – somewhat over 500 here, and 160 sent to England. That, you will see, is a little over 300 copies since the first of August, which I think is not bad at all.
I have just had rather an unpleasant passage of arms with William Carlos Williams. I am sending you the correspondence. The first letter I took as half a joke, and answered accordingly. It was either a joke or an insult – I preferred to take it as the former. The second letter admitted of no question. I enclose a copy of my answer. You were quite right in suspecting that "Others" had gone to the wall, and it proves to me more conclusively than anything else could, that art which is not sincere has no chance. It may make a splash for five minutes, but it counts for nothing in the long run. You will see from Williams’s letter how active our friend Ezra is in distributing lies. To be sure, he lied to me about Hilda before I knew her, and about Lawrence before I knew him, and in neither case had he the same motive for falsifying facts that he has now. I like Williams, and I believe him to be sincere. He is evidently terribly bitter over the failure of “Others”, and utterly bamboozled by Ezra. I feel sure that he will not come to see me when I am in New York. I think he is too upset to desire to be just. It is as well to know how matters stand with that group, although they can’t hurt us in any way.
But this letter of Williams’s, and the failure of “Others” makes me feel a little differently about the publication of the 1917 "Anthology”. I think now that it is well to print it, in order to show them and the public at large that we have not gone under in the “Others” crash, that our movement is still flourishing.
I have sent copies of the Williams correspondence to Hilda, and I suppose she will show it to Richard. And I have also told her just what I think about the "Anthology", and that I think it is well to keep it up through this year, as we planned.
I don’t believe in five years anything will be heard of the Ezra group. I am sorry for Ezra, he had such an overwhelming conceit that it must be hard to find himself kicking about in a backwater. But he has only himself to thank.
